results.title: Senate Confirms Biden’s Pick to Lead E.P.A.
results.abstract: Michael S. Regan has said he intends to act aggressively in carrying out the president’s agenda of fighting climate change.

results.title: Sickle Cell Treatment Not Linked to Cancer, Researchers Say
results.abstract: Trials of experimental gene therapy for sickle cell disease were halted when patients developed worrying illnesses.

results.title: Las mujeres informan de peores efectos secundarios tras la vacuna para la covid
results.abstract: Los hombres y las mujeres suelen responder de forma diferente a muchos tipos de vacunas. Esto se debe probablemente a una mezcla de factores, como las hormonas, los genes y la dosis de las vacunas.

multimedia.caption: Los investigadores de los CDC analizaron los datos de seguridad de 13,7 millones de vacunas para la COVID-19 y descubrieron que el 79,1 por ciento de los efectos secundarios notificados procedían de mujeres, aunque solo el 61,2 por ciento de las vacunas se habían administrado a mujeres.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Kai Chen para The New York Times

results.title: China and Russia Agree to Explore the Moon Together
results.abstract: The two countries, moving increasingly closer, signed a memorandum of agreement to collaborate on lunar missions, including the establishment of a research station in orbit or on the surface of the moon.

multimedia.caption: The Chang’e-5 spacecraft launched in Wenchang, China, in November. China and Russia have said they will build a lunar research station.

results.title: A Trauma Expert Puts the Meghan and Harry Interview in Context
results.abstract: Commentators describe the couple’s experience as “trauma.” But strictly speaking, trauma is an event that alters your mind, leaving you helpless and terrified.

results.title: Estas babosas marinas pasan por la guillotina para conseguir un cuerpo nuevo
results.abstract: Es un trabajo espeluznante pero alguien tiene que hacerlo: los científicos estudian la regeneración animal en estas criaturas del mar.

results.title: Yearly Lung Cancer Scans Are Advised for People 50 and Over With Shorter Smoking Histories
results.abstract: New advice from an influential panel will make more women and African-Americans eligible for CT scans, but some who need them most may not be able to afford them.
org_facet: United States Preventive Services Task Force
Journal of the American Medical Assn

multimedia.caption: A computed tomography scan of the lungs of a healthy adult man. The panel recommended low-dose CT scans, so-called because they involve a relatively small amount of radiation, and cost about $300.

results.title: Hunting for a Leftover Vaccine? This Site Will Match You With a Clinic.
results.abstract: More than half a million people have signed up for Dr. B, a service that promises to match them with clinics struggling to equitably dole out extra doses before they expire.

results.title: How Bad Was 2020 for Tourism? Look at the Numbers.
results.abstract: The dramatic effects of the coronavirus pandemic on the travel industry and beyond are made clear in six charts.
results.byline: By Stephen Hiltner and Lalena Fisher

results.title: Women Report Worse Side Effects After a Covid Vaccine
results.abstract: Men and women tend to respond differently to many kinds of vaccines. That’s probably because of a mix of factors, including hormones, genes and the dosing of the shots.

multimedia.caption: C.D.C. researchers analyzed safety data from 13.7 million Covid-19 vaccinations, finding 79.1 percent of reported side effects came from women, though only 61.2 percent of the vaccines had been administered to women.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

results.title: Global Warming’s Deadly Combination: Heat and Humidity
results.abstract: A new study suggests that large swaths of the tropics will experience dangerous living and working conditions if global warming isn’t limited to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

multimedia.caption: A farmer in Peukan Biluy village in Aceh, Indonesia, part of the region that could become uninhabitable if global temperatures rise too much.

results.title: For Planet Earth, No Tourism is a Curse and a Blessing
results.abstract: From the rise in poaching to the waning of noise pollution, travel’s shutdown is having profound effects. Which will remain, and which will vanish?

results.title: The Virus Spread Where Restaurants Reopened or Mask Mandates Were Absent
results.abstract: C.D.C. researchers found that coronavirus infections and death rates rose in U.S. counties permitting in-person dining or not requiring masks.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: “You have decreases in cases and deaths when you wear masks, and you have increases in cases and deaths when you have in-person restaurant dining,” Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, said Friday.

“You have decreases in cases and deaths when you wear masks, and you have increases in cases and deaths when you have in-person restaurant dining,” Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, said Friday.

results.title: L.G.B.T.Q. People Face Increased Risks From Covid, but Many Don’t Want the Vaccine
results.abstract: Evidence suggests that some sexual and gender minorities — especially people of color — are hesitant to get vaccinated due to mistrust of the medical establishment.

results.title: In Oregon, Scientists Find a Virus Variant With a Worrying Mutation
results.abstract: In a single sample, geneticists discovered a version of the coronavirus first identified in Britain with a mutation originally reported in South Africa.

multimedia.caption: Coronavirus testing at the Virginia Garcia clinic in Hillsboro, Ore., last year. A variant found in Oregon may have evolved with a mutation that blunts the body’s immune response.

results.title: Wisdom, the World’s Oldest Known Wild Bird, Has Another Chick
results.abstract: An albatross named Wisdom has astounded researchers by hatching a chick at more than 70 years old, securing her title as the world’s oldest known breeding bird.

multimedia.caption: The Laysan albatross named Wisdom, who was first identified and banded on Midway Atoll in 1956, has hatched a chick at the age of at least 70.
multimedia.copyright: John Klavitter/U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service

results.title: Can Long-Term Care Employers Require Staff Members to Be Vaccinated?

results.title: Popular Drug Does Not Alleviate Mild Covid-19 Symptoms, Study Finds
results.abstract: Ivermectin, a drug typically used to treat parasitic worms, has been prescribed widely during the coronavirus pandemic, but rigorous data has been lacking.
org_facet: Journal of the American Medical Assn

multimedia.caption: Ivermectin does not speed recovery in people with mild cases of Covid-19, according to a randomized controlled trial published in the journal JAMA today.
